@patio11 @ByrneHobart Yes, having to win and retain customer loyalty is often (but isn't *necessarily*) conducive to organizational accountability… but there are certainly other ways of achieving it too. Whatever its etiology, though, past 12 months have demonstrated an often tragic paucity.

text: RT @gasca: A lot happened in 2020 but the one thing I can’t shake is our inability to tackle climate change... so I wrote up what I’ve been…
@can Post itself isn’t the point.
@sean_a_cassidy @tylercowen Not the point!

@codinghorror Not sure but I’m not sure the principle changes a great deal in either case? (To be clear, I think that the platforms have every *right* to remove the content no matter what. But that doesn’t mean that we have to agree with the policy!)

@codinghorror Yeah, that’s clearly the right fallback (and the one he pursued). But social networks exist to disseminate information. If he could (hypothetically) host his content without issue but not spread it on any platform, that’s presumably still something that should give us some pause?

These platforms have tough jobs, no doubt. But I’m worried that the embrace of “misinformation” as a newly illegitimate category may have costs that are considerably greater than what’s apparent at the outset.

Science is not a coherent, monolithic edifice. It changes daily and scientists don’t all agree with each other. A lot of ex post correct views first show up as claims that look ridiculous by the standards of the time. https://t.co/T9DDZ2Dnwz

text:
@michael_nielsen Yup... yesterday's tweet was that side. https://t.co/38HRqbTUY8

Nonetheless, I think we shouldn't downplay the /fast part. Why was COVID-19 the disease we developed a vaccine for so quickly? Were we incredibly lucky or did we approach the problem meaningfully differently?
@CJHandmer Hah. Pretty sure immune system unpredictability means that you need to rerun upon essentially every meaningful perturbation.

Two caveats:

1) While the Phase III data look very good, it's still quite early.

2) The BioNTech timeline was essentially equally impressive. Pointers specific development dates would be welcome.

@ZackCCordero That said, I think that most productive reform today will be *within* that which is understood to be “the scientific enterprise”, vs trying to change external circumstances.
@ZackCCordero That said, I’m in strong agreement with your point (as I understand it): external circumstances have driven major changes in nature of scientific enterprise.

@ZackCCordero I’m somewhat unconvinced by the MBA story (though recent Arora paper definitely interesting here). I do think firm organization has changed substantially, exact character and causality very complicated.

@ZackCCordero Yes, contemporary use of metrics in science truly awful. Nonetheless, problems seems endogenous to me (if one includes institutions and funding mechanisms). Would welcome a discussion any time!

@ZackCCordero My partner worked in Feng Zhang’s lab and I think very highly of CRISPR! Amazing tool.

At a high level, how do you think we should study the health of (and rate of) progress in science? Are there analyses that could in principle change your view?

text: @davecraige @bgurley The relevant question is what the new general equilibrium will be, after accounting for relevant costs, elasticities, and trade-offs. The article frames the problem as a moral issue, as if it’s about the apportionment of a free lunch. It’s just not a serious analysis.

@Noahpinion Yeah, but you have to disaggregate beyond topline. Productivity of firms making effective use of ICT is very high and lots of evidence for growing dispersion in firm-level productivity. Plus mismeasurement questions persist. Don’t think statement can be reasonably seen as true.

@Noahpinion I think “TFP growth slowed” and “By 2005 or so, it will become clear that the Internet's impact on the economy has been no greater than the fax machine's” are very (very) different statements.

text: @daniel_levine I’m not saying that it should be dispositive (though I think there should be a strong presumption in favor of people’s own agency); just that I find it underreported.
@SurveyBrent @mjamurphy Agree. https://t.co/GnBbQ4eVku https://t.co/MAtPItpp1z
(If anyone knows of more comprehensive surveys with public results, please let me know.)
@mjamurphy Importantly, both are quite consistent. Would be very interested to see contrary data if it exists.
@mjamurphy This is just the survey I can publicly tweet about, unfortunately. Other data better but proprietary/internal.

In all of the discussion about AB5, it seems underreported that a significant majority of the tech platform workers seem to prefer the contractor model.

Below survey done by former driver. (https://t.co/VfjQBK5Vyo.) Different company found 80% majority prefer contractor status. https://t.co/mFNkwXMbMF
@Noahpinion Often wish the referents covered by the “believe science” exhortation popular in this group could be considered to include empirical findings on the price elasticities of housing supply.
@AdamsPublius @Noahpinion Interesting -- have a link?

@AntiIlliberal @Noahpinion I wouldn't call it that -- I've found vast majority of every generation to be highly tolerant -- but, yes, certain highly opinionated / moralizing perspectives create cultural challenges for Stripe and for almost every other company whose leaders I've spoken with.
@angelina @stewartbrand @Noahpinion Can you expand on this?
@stewartbrand @Noahpinion I guess “How does Irish entrepreneurialism differ from Weber-ian entrepreneurialism?” might be an interesting question.

@stewartbrand @Noahpinion Theologically lapsed for sure; hard for me to tell how culturally embedded in Catholicism per se! (Probably need my friends to judge that...) I do feel distinctly *Irish* on the whole.
@joesmith323 @Noahpinion Interesting! Though Green Party representation in Ireland and Germany not currently dissimilar. (It’s possible that this is an anomaly compared to average trend, of course.)
@cameron_parker @Noahpinion @JohnHMcWhorter I look forward to it!
@Noahpinion Linking to this tweet to unify the thread: https://t.co/7AYPvRkkcR https://t.co/DWPpW1FQ4q
@Noahpinion It does seem true that there are many parallels to Christianity more broadly, so maybe this objection just suggests a minor refinement.

@Noahpinion It’s an interesting thesis. However, wouldn’t it seem to predict that these ideas won’t garner as many adherents in (say) traditionally Catholic countries? And yet Ireland seems quite receptive.

@AgnesCallard @michael_nielsen In the abstract, I think it'd mean steep declines in (1) production of good new explanations for phenomena of interest, (2) identification of new material problems/desires, and (3) generation of new ways to solve our problems. But maybe that's just a restatement of your question?

@AgnesCallard @michael_nielsen Been thinking more about this. When you say "how would we know", could you clarify what you're looking for? (Something abstract/conceptual or something more like a metric?)

text: @mrgunn @TimSteeno @tomcritchlow Won’t find any argument here! https://t.co/4Qcdo2qG4y https://t.co/MWmL9TWqkl
@nabeelqu @AgnesCallard Yeah, fully agree, and I interpret Callard as fairly specifically critiquing academic philosophy. (I’m more optimistic than she is about that being done by the laity.)

@nicholaspaul26 @AgnesCallard Yeah, I fully grant that these things ebb and flow a bit. I just worry that it’s easy to use this as an excuse in areas in which some dynamics may be going awry, particularly given how often it seems to have been contemporaneously clear when things *were* working.

@nicholaspaul26 @AgnesCallard Is it? I think people knew that Rorty, Rawls, and Nozick were very important even at the time. (I think this is often true of fertile periods -- the physicists of the 20s knew that it was a special moment. Ditto people during Renaissance, etc.)

On trends in academic philosophy, @AgnesCallard:

https://t.co/25u2BVXDLu https://t.co/2ySlymnCnr

A service to turn blog archives into (optionally paid?) email newsletters could be pretty neat. There are a lot of blogs I missed the heydays of but whose archives contain a great deal of hard-to-consume gold.

@RealTimeWWII x @SubstackInc x @WordPress, basically.

@ctbeiser Yes, the simple fact that Rubio is publicly saying this is the story IMO. Seems a not-everyday utterance from someone in his position?

https://t.co/7JnmNuG9oy https://t.co/O1F8JTvLYK
@ctbeiser In that way, the story if anything seems quite under-reported to me.

@ctbeiser Interesting. As with Fermi paradox itself, every resolution to this story seems quite interesting and noteworthy to me. (Deliberate misinformation (why?), deep and pervasive misunderstanding (how?), hitherto-unknown technology/phenomenon (what?), etc.)

@ctbeiser Don’t follow — do you think it’s not noteworthy that Reid and Rubio (latter acting chair of Senate intelligence committee and member of Gang of Eight) are themselves talking about UFOs, no matter what the eventual explanation proves to be?

text: Businesses launched on @Stripe since lockdowns began in March have -- somewhat incredibly -- already generated more than $1 billion in aggregate revenue. We're very glad to be able to play our part in helping them sell, adapt, and grow.

text: @tdietterich @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Agree that CS seems much healthier (perhaps in part because it's much less costly than biomedicine). Out of curiosity, do you attribute ~all of the outperformance of HHMI investigators to selection effects? (This paper attempts to control for that: https://t.co/aLEzYQYypM.)

@tdietterich @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion You're a scientist and I'm not, so feel free to push back or tell me I'm totally wrong :-). But my POV is informed by dozens of conversations with practicing scientists and also senior managers at NIH/NSF.

@tdietterich @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion I'm not saying that one is a priori better than the other. Just that the NIH (or NSF) embody definite mechanisms that incentivize certain things and discourage others.

@tdietterich @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Yes, because it's nowhere close to being fully general (like a CPU). The mechanism of study sections is very different to hypothetical alternative mechanism where independent agents can of own volition give $5M to a lab.
@tdietterich @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion The structure itself is the monoculture.
@ArtirKel @Noahpinion @roybahat @brogram_ I wonder about this and related questions a lot -- both nature of supply itself and characteristics of its allocation.
@Noahpinion @roybahat @brogram_ Or more simply stated: phenomenon you describe is IMO a predictable outcome de facto monopsony.
@Noahpinion @roybahat @brogram_ 💯

urls.title: Fast Grants
urls.description: Funding for scientists at academic institutions working on COVID-19 related projects.

text:
@Noahpinion @roybahat @brogram_ As you know from https://t.co/jnHxcrJJk0, I think this is a big problem!

As we see in industries with competition between funders (like tech), the right incentive structure should invert this, and make the funding agencies hunt for the best scientists.

@Noahpinion @roybahat @brogram_ Point being: we spend *enormous* amounts of money today. But efficacy with which we do so seems quite poor. (We've discovered *one* broad-spectrum antiviral drug since Fauci took over NIAID 36(!!) years ago[1]. Is the problem really insufficient funding?)

https://t.co/5AtDbZfOa0

text: RT @seancblanton: https://t.co/GpD1XF24xI is one of the finest examples of data visualization and storytelling I've ever seen.

@NickPinkston @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion @DARPA To me it is Progress Studies :-). In terms of books about funding agencies, the genre is sadly sparse. (Part of the reason we decided to promulgate a new term!) I know of *zero* recent works about NIH or NSF. A few about DARPA but they're too breathless.
@NickPinkston @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion @DARPA Not quantitative but you've probably seen https://t.co/9LnyGMLkA3.

@roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Maybe? On the one hand, overwhelming majority of important discoveries haven’t come from gargantuan efforts. On the other hand, I would be fully supportive of some of our sharded funding bodies experimenting with this approach. I’m skeptical it’ll work but experimentation good!
@roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion LHC some of the lowest-ROI science ever done! I’m not *against* funding it but it sure isn’t an example of a healthy funding ecosystem IMO.
@NickPinkston @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Agree

@roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Peer review much less important that funding, in my view. Tenure system isn’t great but is in many ways also determined by funding. (“Who’s going to prosper in this system?”)

text: @roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion DOE/DOD not that relevant for most scientists. And DOE budget dwarfed by NIH. Certainly better than nothing, yes. I think gargantuan funding institutions are bad because they force ecosystem to adapt to their preferences. (Not doing so is an irrational career strategy.)
@roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion Break up NIH and NSF into 10+ bodies with fully independent approaches. Every 5-10 years, reassess their budgets. Hegemonic monoculture today very pernicious.

@roybahat @brogram_ @Noahpinion I’m generally supportive of more funding for science in principle but I *would* say that lack of money is not the primary problem today and that the marginal returns to additional funding would be (have been!) slight.

urls.title: Rethinking Antibiotic Research and Development: World War II and the Penicillin Collaborative
urls.description: Policy leaders and public health experts may be overlooking effective ways to stimulate innovative antibiotic research and development. I analyzed archival resources concerning the US government’s efforts to produce penicillin during World War ...

text: RT @CiaraBreath: @patrickc https://t.co/SzZhrYSBAn https://t.co/eappSY87wz
There might be better coverage elsewhere but best I've found is in medical chapters of https://t.co/8S32R1JLzK.
There's lots of precedent for rapid, successful, directed medical research led/coordinated by US Government.
These programs were *fast*. (Just over one year from formation of board to coordinate work on malaria to getting the first therapeutics shipped.)

Hard to find good stuff online but WWII Committee on Medical Research probably has useful lessons. In very short order, figured out how to scale penicillin production, found better malaria antivirals (including chloroquine!), huge improvements in blood transfusions/replacements…
@kevinriggle @isaach https://t.co/0V8uWSClMp

@david_perell @danwwang @david_perell To be clear, very much agree with the basic point you're making.

Here's life expectancy 1880–2000. Increasing more slowly despite roughly exponential increase in research spending. https://t.co/VQoGQWaBWX

@varma_ashwin97 @david_perell @danwwang Per our other branch in the thread, I basically agree with you, though isn't use of mortality statistics largely because cancer researchers themselves have decided to benchmark progress on mortality rates?

@david_perell @danwwang I think that's from Rise and Fall of American Growth. (At least, it's *originally* from there.) It's a very striking chart but it's not clear to me exactly what's being computed and how. E.g., how are cohort effects accounted for? (And I presume chart label is just mistaken...)

@varma_ashwin97 @ArtirKel @albrgr @danwwang I think these are all good points. I don't personally have a strong view on the question. Does seem surprising to me that this analysis isn't pursued more actively by e.g. NCI -- it should be easy to find a definitive analysis. (And Scott shouldn't have had to write his post…)

@jasonwbade @albrgr @danwwang Right. To be clear, I don’t think it’s *just* the advocacy groups. Study sections, to your point, are also a very pro-status quo force. (If you wanted to deliberately create institutional intertia, you’d design something like that.)
@jamesNbeaumont @jasonwbade @albrgr @danwwang That’d take more than a tweet :-).

@jasonwbade @albrgr @danwwang Simply that if they reduce funding for any area or approach, they’re immediately on receiving end of anger from very (justifiably) motivated lobby groups. Those groups will happily go to Congress if needed. Congress sets the budget...
@jasonwbade @albrgr @danwwang In short, yes. NIH is screwed up (he agreed with all the usual critiques) but also more constrained by patient advocacy groups than might be obvious.
@albrgr @danwwang Yeah, he wasn’t denying that particular breakthroughs have happened. Just arguing that *overall* improvement (lifestyle- and detection-adjusted) has been slight.
@danwwang I thought this was interesting since local incentives presumably push him to be *optimistic* about rate of progress.

@danwwang A very senior US cancer funding official recently told me that his view is that we’ve made very little progress in treatment since 1971. (And, to your point, that most mortality curves are confounded by non-treatment factors.)

@Pinboard Difference is that our product doesn’t create the temporally fixed repayment obligations that can drive a business into bankruptcy. Repayment is instead indexed to the business trajectory, which is much safer.
@Pinboard Agree! But doesn’t that argue for more rather than fewer capital products like this?

@Pinboard Yes; see other tweet. If a business has better options, they should pursue those — we aren’t trying to create a product that all seek to use. This exists because businesses consistently report substantial capital constraints (and credit cards are far from being a panacea).
@Pinboard If a business has cheaper/lower-risk access to capital, they should certainly pursue that. Point is: many don’t.

@Pinboard An APR isn’t directly comparable because this structure yields far less risk for the business. I elaborate here: https://t.co/NDOQkYVayE. As a result, 90%+ of business owners who use this rate their satisfaction 6/7 or 7/7.

@albrgr's collection of papers on the health effects of air pollution.
He doesn't date it. Simply says it was drawn up "long ago" at Los Alamos National Lab.

In The Art of Doing Science and Engineering, Hamming gives this amazing sigmoidal formulation for the growth rate of computing power: e^(22(1-e^(-t/20))), with t=0 in 1943.

That predicts 2.2 GHz for 2019, with is rather remarkably close to where we are.

urls.title: Patrick Collison on Innovation and Scientific Progress - Econlib
urls.description: Patrick Collison, co-founder and CEO of Stripe, talks with EconTalk host Russ Roberts about the pace of innovation. Collison argues that despite enormous increases in the numbers of scientists and researchers, the pace of progress in scientific and technological understanding does not seem to be increasing accordingly. The conversation looks at the challenge of measuring […]

text: Am generally pretty optimistic about Stripe. Part of the job, honestly. But, man, if we ship even half of what‘s planned for 2019, the year is going to be a true lollapalooza.

One interesting challenge is making it work well for both the smallest startups and for internet's largest businesses (some listed at https://t.co/F1Hayjo6Y4) -- lots of dynamic adaptation needed. If this is of interest to you, we're hiring.

Over the past year, we've been building out free, 24x7 phone/chat technical support at scale -- an important but less obvious part of making internet economy more accessible. Still some way to go but proud of the progress we made in 2018. https://t.co/FsNT1xKVJs

@kevinakwok @michael_nielsen It’s just a Google Doc:

Area
• [Goal]
    • [Next step]

Goals without next steps then stick out (that’s part of where priming comes in…). I update the next steps at least weekly, as part of review. I move completed goals to bottom—feels good, plus fun end-of-year review.

text: @alexstamos Varies by team but, in general, we’re fans. Some of our highest-impact people have been remote since they started. It’s not all easy (and does require adaptation by others), but it is definitely worth it IMO.

We still haven’t quite figured out the right UI paradigms for deep work…

But for close collaboration on a deadline, technology is now *great*. AirDrop, Slack, WhatsApp, Google Drive, Google Docs, Zoom. Things are so much better than they were a decade ago.

@bppfeiffer @GrahamMOliver The conditional was rhetorical; of course they matter. I am many of things but not skeptical of the value of books. https://t.co/1O14jlIb36

@rachsyme For sure. I guess my view is "now that we've found that books are so wonderful, maybe some other book-like things might be great too." In taking books seriously as artifacts, seems that we should probably invest more in experimentation around them.

@BrandyLJensen There are probably also substantially different individual preferences at play. More broadly, I guess I'm in favor of more experimentation here. What we have today seems quite contingent. If books are so great (i.e., my view), maybe many other book-like things could be too.

@BrandyLJensen I happen to know Florent a little and I'm pretty sure he loves books. (As do I. https://t.co/TD15aN5H7M.) I think there are different modalities at play... "maximizing rate of comprehension" vs "enjoying Ferrante", etc.
@rachsyme The question was rhetorical; few things I love more... https://t.co/1O14jlIb36

@aarieff The question was rhetorical; of course they matter a lot. But books as they exist today are a technology. An amazing technology. And I doubt we've yet perfected them... we invented indexes, e-books, paperbacks over the years. Further improvement seems possible.

@BrandyLJensen Well, I think the idea would be that you'd only follow people whose annotations you actually appreciated. (And nobody, if you want.) Although the people who don't like books are probably not annotating very much...

Congrats, @edelwax and @tristanharris.

text: RT @jeiting: We used Atlas for @RevenueCat and the whole experience has been awesome. The team is great and the community has been fantasti…

And it's partly because all available data suggests that there should, in some sense, be many more startups than there are -- we appear to be far short of the efficient frontier. See, e.g. https://t.co/lV9b36rcYY. These charts are crazy. https://t.co/HGq5d5MAsq

Partly, it's because there are great economies of scale in productizing the solutions. Even the very best entrepreneurs are not any better at the mechanics of establishing their companies. (And sometimes even they make big mistakes.)

It may be worth touching on why we're building Atlas. Partly, it's to make access to infrastructure for entrepreneurship as broadly and cheaply available as possible. Talent is uniformly distributed... but opportunity is not. We want to help correct that.

text: @blaine Because I want to help cultivate a group/community.
@markessien Congrats!
@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject I’ll check it out, thanks! (And thanks for creating Mastodon...)
@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject (Private groups.)
@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject That seems reasonable to me but I think you need *some* way to support groups.
@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject Also, how does URL privacy work? Security-through-reachability?
@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject Ah, neat. Maybe a “require approval for non-instance follows” would help a lot, then :-). (To avoid friction on the instance itself.)

@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject So you’re saying that if my account is locked (and my followers are on the same instance), “public” posts will show up in the instance’s local feed and my followers’ feeds, but nowhere else?
@kinkymal @Gargron @MastodonProject But not from people who’ve locked their accounts (to prevent people from outside the instance following them), right?

@Gargron @kinkymal @MastodonProject Thanks, that’s helpful... but if you imagine a 1,000-person invite-only instance, it’d be nice to have navigability / discoverability *within* it. And the ability to follow people without needing approval each time.
@Plinz @stewartbrand Maybe, yeah, but I think it’s psychologically hard to separate it all...
@qtname Oh, awesome! It’d be neat if the privacy protection was just a bit more robust. But this seems close to exactly what I was looking for.

@stewartbrand Mastodon is an open source, self-hostable Twitter clone. Since Twitter itself is so beset with outrage and politics these days, have been considering setting up a separate place for the people I know who want something different. I don’t know if it would work.

RT @nelhage: @patrickc One of my working perspectives is that Silicon Valley is substantially an engine for generating positive tail outcom…
RT @nelhage: @patrickc It does feel like a lot of questions in these debates come down in large part to optimizing for the median vs optimi…
@nelhage Yup.
@josh_wills @rabois Indeed I do already regret not starting this by thanking him for the covfefe he's giving the issue.
Maybe they're useful to disentangle. Latter feels like an empirical question; former is of course just about values and has no right answer.
and, separately, to what degree intensity of application *causes* the latter.
Feels to me disagreement is over two separate things: what it is that people *should* be optimizing for (quality of life vs tail outcomes)…
(Much easier to endorse comfortable balance.)
@rabois No snark meant -- it's an important question for all of us, and he's giving voice to a harder-to-argue perspective.
I've been enjoying reading @rabois's debate with others over past day or two on the importance of hard work.
And https://t.co/72N2aav19l, which is very readable and quite unsettling.
@lippytak Could well be true, yes, though I think there's more: for me also about giving yourself permission to contemplate the faintly ridiculous.
(By "a hack", I just mean something that sounds implausible at first blush. Without that, too likely it's already been attempted.)
Enumerating those characteristics sounds mundane, but I've started to notice more such ideas since putting the traits together.
Interesting category of ideas: things that are cheap, leveraged/scalable, and some kind of hack. ("CLH".) YC being an obvious example.
Neat paper; interesting to set alongside https://t.co/J5iw3bhWG2 and https://t.co/l2zWWEkecF.

@StephenPiment My core point is just that demand isn't fixed -- and with positive returns to marginal scale, dynamics might surprise.
@StephenPiment Singapore population was 750k in 1940. Could it have become as affluent as it is without growing population? My guess is no.
@StephenPiment I think it likely would be. Look at rent in the small cities that aren't Seoul or Singapore!
@Sharkyl @Noahpinion @p_ganong I think it would help! It would increase returns to scale for everyone… and maybe also decrease prices :-).

@p_ganong @Noahpinion a huge amount of housing before you beat returns to scale. Would SF housing be long-term cheaper with 50% more supply?
